timeline.summary: On July 24, 2019, a Notice of Appearance for Additional Counsel was filed in the case of United States of America v. Epstein (Case Number 19-2221) before the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit. The notice was filed on behalf of the Appellee, the United States of America, by Reid Weingarten and Donnell G. Bolden. The document, titled "Moe NOA.pdf," was electronically stamped and stored within the notice cart.

Emails exchanged between individuals regarding contact with the Palm Beach Sheriff’s Office in relation to an investigation, specifically concerning Jeffrey Epstein’s time serving a sentence. Communication occurred with the Palm Beach Police Department and the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Southern District of New York. Updates were provided regarding contact attempts, a device analysis, and a planned interview. Redactions were present in the document.

On August 5, 2019, a “CURED DEFECTIVE NOTICE OF ADDITIONAL COUNSEL” was filed in the case of *United States of America v. Epstein* (Case Number 19-2221) by Jeffrey Epstein’s legal team, represented by Reid Weingarten and associates at Steptoe & Johnson. The notice was filed with the 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals. The document is identified as EFTA00028078 and was subsequently stored in the court’s notice cart for Quality Control 1. Access to the document is permitted for attorneys of record and parties involved in the case, with PACER fees applying to other users.

On August 5, 2019, a “Notice of Appearance for Additional or Substitute Counsel” was filed in the case of *United States of America v. Epstein* (Case Number 19-2221) before the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit. The notice was filed on behalf of Jeffrey Epstein by CM/ECF and indicates the document was electronically mailed and stored in the notice cart for Quality Control and the Deputy Clerk. The document itself is titled “Epstein_MGW Notice of Appearance for Additional Counsel_final.pdf”.

On August 6, 2019, the Court of Appeals, 2nd Circuit, recorded a docket activity transaction for the case of United States of America v. Epstein (Case Number: 19-2221). Martin G. Weinberg and Reid Weingarten were added as attorneys of record. The document was labeled EFTA00020942 and stored in the notice cart for Quality Control 1. A note indicates judicial conference policy allows attorneys and parties to receive free electronic copies, with PACER fees applying to others.

A communication chain discusses the processing and analysis of electronic items related to a CART (Computer Assisted Response Team) investigation, identified as EFTA00037385. Approximately 12 electronic devices were imaged and processed, including 3 iPads, 1 iPhone, 1 iMac (locked), 1 external hard drive (encrypted), and various Windows boxes and thumb drives.  No devices have been reviewed due to a pending taint review. The status is to be updated following an impending search.

An email chain discusses the processing and analysis of electronic devices related to the Epstein case, specifically referencing a "CART" (Child Exploitation and Human Trafficking Task Force) investigation. Approximately 12 devices were imaged and processed, including iPads, iPhones, iMacs, and external hard drives. One iMac was locked and un-imageable, and some media was encrypted and unreadable. No devices had been reviewed at the time of the last update, pending a taint review. A fax cover sheet request was made for TPS reports.

On August 9, 2019, an individual provided a rough estimate of electronic items processed as part of a CART (Computer Analysis Response Team) investigation related to Jeffrey Epstein. The items included 3 iPads, 1 iPhone, 1 iMac (locked and un-imaged), 1 external hard drive (encrypted and imaged), 2 iMacs (imaged and processed), 2 Windows boxes (imaged and processed), 1 laptop (imaged and processed), and various loose media (hard drives, thumb drives).  Nothing had been reviewed due to a pending taint review, and a more detailed status was expected after an impending search.

On August 10, 2019, at 4:30 PM EDT, one Seagate Barracuda 500GB HDD (Serial Number 23T6CF5X) was collected from a redacted location as part of an investigation related to Jeffrey Epstein’s death. The evidence originated from a Nice Vision DVR2 Surveillance System and was submitted under case ID 90A-NY-3151227. The receipt was not given. The item is designated as original and numbered as 1.

On August 10, 2019, at 4:30 PM EDT, one Hitachi 500GB HDD (Serial Number JP1572JE36A13K) was collected from a redacted location by the MCC-NY as part of a CART evidence submission (NYC023579) related to a death investigation. The HDD was recovered from a Nice Vision DVR2 surveillance system. The receipt was not given.

On August 10, 2019, at 4:30 PM EDT, one Hitachi 500GB HDD (Serial JP1572JE36MWNK) was collected from a redacted location as part of a death investigation (Case ID: 90A-NY-3151227). The HDD was recovered from a MCC Nice Vision DVR2 Surveillance System and submitted under NYC023582. Receipt was not given.

On August 10, 2019, at 4:30 PM EDT, one Seagate Constellation ES 500GB HDD (Serial Number Z1M1PZPE) was collected from MCC-NY as evidence related to a death investigation (Case ID: 90A-NY-3151227). The evidence originated from a Nice Vision DVR2 surveillance system (7 of 18). Receipt was not given. The document is an item log from the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The FBI collected a Seagate Barracuda 1000GB hard drive (Serial Z1D3ZSS0) as a derivative copy of another Seagate Barracuda 500GB hard drive (Serial Z3T6CF5X). The original hard drive was collected via TX-1, S/N 000ECC58017156 on 08/12/2019 at 07:00. The evidence was labeled NYC027703 and associated with Request ID 112048. Jeffrey Epstein is listed as the victim in a death investigation.

On August 12, 2019, U.S. District Judge Richard M. Serman wrote to the Warden of the Etta N. Carter Correctional Center regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein. The letter inquired about whether investigations, including one at MCC on or about July 23, 2019, would address the unresolved circumstances surrounding Epstein’s death and the Bureau of Prisons’ conclusions about the incident.

Barr delivered remarks at the 64th National Biennial Conference of the Fraternal Order of Police in New Orleans. The speech focused on several key areas: *   **Jeffrey Epstein Case:** Barr addressed the Department of Justice’s handling of the investigation and security failures surrounding Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in Manhattan, emphasizing the department's commitment to holding those responsible accountable. *   **Law Enforcement Support:** He reaffirmed the Administration's support for law enforcement, praising officers’ bravery and sacrifices, particularly in recent events like the El Paso and Dayton shootings. *   **Crime Reduction Efforts:** Barr highlighted the DOJ's efforts to combat violent crime and the opioid epidemic, referencing past successes and ongoing initiatives like Project Safe Neighborhood and Operation SOS targeting synthetic drugs and Mexican cartels. He stressed the need for sustained funding and support for law enforcement. *   **Community Values:** Barr underscored the importance of community values and the role of law enforcement in maintaining order, referencing James Madison's ideas about self-governance and the "thin blue line." *   **Respect for Police:** He emphasized the need for public respect and understanding of the challenges faced by police officers, particularly in the face of increasing criticism and resistance to police commands. The speech concluded with a call to action, urging the public to appreciate the contributions of law enforcement and reaffirming the Department's commitment to their safety and success.

On August 14, 2019, at 04:30 PM EDT, one Seagate Barracuda 500GB HDD (S/N 9QM8MSRR) was collected from a redacted location as part of a death investigation (Case ID: 90A-NY-3151227). The evidence originated from a Nice Vision DVR2 Surveillance System and was received “No” by MCC-NY. The item was designated as “Original” and collected by an individual named “Seizing Indi.”

A case coordination meeting was scheduled for August 16, 2019, at 10:00 AM at SDNY to discuss strategy following Epstein’s death. Evidence from Little St. James, USVI, was being processed for forensic analysis by the Evidence Control Unit and CART.

The document was stamped with a date and file number.

The hard drive contained verified E01 images numbered NYCO23578 through NYCO23592. The evidence was collected from a redacted location and held at the New York holding office.

On August 23, 2019, a correctional officer (identified as “w”) responded to a body alert in the SHU at the facility regarding Jeffrey Epstein. The officer assisted with CPR, allowed EMS access, and escorted Epstein to Beekman Hospital. Another officer, working with OIG and SDNY, responded to a similar alert where Epstein was already being treated after being removed from his cell. FBI CART provided a video package of the MCC to SDNY, and coordination was made to retrieve and image Thomas’ cell phone. The Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) was contacted and advised that they would provide a report soon, anticipating no further information requests. Three proffers were scheduled for Monday, August 26th, involving inmates from the MCC at the time of the incident, who have a history of facilitating contraband and policy violations.

On August 23, 2019, an FBI-New York investigation regarding Jeffrey Epstein’s death involved interviews with Bureau of Prisons (BOP) guards. One guard reported that another guard and his partner conducted a 12x8 tour, responded to a body alert in the SHU where Epstein was already receiving CPR, and subsequently escorted the body to Beekman Hospital with EMS. Another guard assisted with the count and then responded to a body alert, observing Epstein being removed from his cell and treated. FBI CART packaged video from the MCC for SDNY, and coordination was made to retrieve and image Thomas’ cell phone. The Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) advised that a final report would be provided soon, with a physician and executive having a meeting regarding the autopsy. Three proffers involving inmates from the MCC were scheduled for Monday, August 26th.

FBI New York is coordinating daily conference calls at 3:30 PM regarding the Epstein case. The calls utilize the VCAC Bridge Line. Information regarding “dial-in details” is being forwarded between FBI agents and [REDACTED]. The purpose of the calls is to discuss aspects of the case and forensics, with a focus on a jail incident.  SSA, FBI New York, CID (FBI), and ASAC personnel are involved in these daily calls.

An FBI representative from NY CART will be on a call regarding details of a call involving Jeffrey Epstein. The request was made to include an OTD POC, NY CART POC, SAC, ASAC VC/VCAC, SSA VC, A/SSA VC, SSA VCAC, SSA PC, SSA CR, and MAC from the New York Field Office’s Criminal – Branch C desk.  The call was scheduled for August 26, 2019.

On August 27, 2019, an FBI investigation (Serial 90A-NY-3151227) involving an Apple iPhone XS (IMEI: 1B44, iOS 12.4) was conducted. An ITS/Forensic Examiner performed a file system extraction using GrayKey v1.11.10 in response to MDUS request 110754. No unlock PIN was associated with the device. A SHA256 hash was generated, and extraction files were copied to an external hard drive. The extracted item and resulting evidence were returned to the New York CART, and the examination portion is considered complete. The document is FBI property and restricted for distribution outside the agency.

This document is an official report from the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Digital Evidence Laboratory (DEL REX) regarding the examination of evidence items 1B1 to 1618. The report, dated 09/10/2019, details the uploading of a CART Process Report for cloning and imaging processes related to a death investigation involving Jeffrey Epstein as a victim (Case ID: 90A-NY-3151227). The report is classified as UNCLASSIFIED.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New MI requested photos of the SHU and data regarding the number of steps from Epstein’s cell to the guard desk from an unidentified sender. The request included a need for a 100GB hard drive for FBI CART to download material. Will was asked to request the hard drive from IT.

An FBI agent (NY) forwarded an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney (Southern District of New York) regarding materials from a search of Jeffrey Epstein’s New York house. The email requests information on the number of electronic devices (approximately 38 computers/devices and 55 CDs) sent to CART for processing, and asks for contact information for the CART team.

An FBI agent (NY) sent an email to Mina regarding search warrant materials from the New York house search related to Jeffrey Epstein. The agent states that load files containing over 800,000 emails are incomplete due to a limitation of 25,000 entries per file. Priority was given to materials from “the Island” with an expiration date. All content is available for taint review in FTK. The agent previously contacted a senior forensic examiner regarding Epstein evidence processed by CART, and an Assistant U.S. Attorney requested information on the number of electronic devices sent to CART and those subsequently processed. Approximately 38 computers/storage devices and 55 CDs were seized and sent to CART for processing.

An FBI agent (Senior Forensic Examiner) requested a call to discuss a list of materials received by CART regarding search warrant materials from the New York house search related to Jeffrey Epstein. An Assistant U.S. Attorney contacted the Senior Forensic Examiner to inquire about the number of electronic devices (approximately 38 computers/devices and 55 CDs) sent to CART for processing and the number that were subsequently returned. The Senior Forensic Examiner had already contacted someone who handled Epstein evidence and was able to provide information about the materials processed.

A U.S. Attorney’s office (Southern District of New York) requested information regarding materials recovered during a New York house search warrant. The request specifically asks for a detailed count of electronic devices (phones, computers, hard drives, thumb drives, and discs) sent to CART for processing, and the number that were subsequently processed and returned. The initial report indicated approximately 38 computers/storage devices and 55 CDs were seized.

On October 9, 2019, an FBI agent (NY) informed a recipient that load files containing over 800,000 emails from a New York search warrant related to Jeffrey Epstein were not yet completed due to a limitation of 25,000 entries per file. Priority was given to materials from “the Island.” The FBI had seized approximately 38 computers and 55 CDs from the search. The taint team received documents from the search but noted a lower-than-expected number of documents. The agent directed the recipient to contact someone who handled the Epstein evidence for answers regarding processing.

On November 20, 2019, the FBI’s New York Division requested a forensic examination of an Apple iPhone Xs (model A1920, S/N: F17XD9PKKPFW, IMEI: 357208091738649) obtained via Consent to Search. The examination, conducted by the Computer Analysis Response Team (CART), involved a physical inventory, data extractions from the device and SIM card using commercial software, and a request for a full file system extraction. Data was extracted on 9/17/2019, and a report was generated.  Two archived copies of the data were created and released to the New York Division Evidence Control Unit: 1644_NYCO25647 and 1646_NYFO1278. The Sprint SIM Card (ICCID: 89312530002006358152) was also extracted and archived.

This is an official FBI Import Form, dated November 21, 2019, titled “CART Process Report for CART Submission ID:218509.” The report relates to a death investigation with Jeffrey Epstein as a victim (Case ID S: 90A-NY-3151227) and was approved by the SSA. The form is marked as UNCLASSIFIED and includes the case number EFTA00035749.

This document is an unofficial Federal Bureau of Investigation Import Form, dated December 11, 2019, related to a digital evidence examination. It concerns Process Report #223558 regarding CART technical assistance for case ID #90A-NY-3151227, involving Jeffrey Epstein as a victim and a death investigation. The form was received on October 16, 2009.

A Senior Forensic Examiner is generating load files related to electronic evidence from a New York residence search connected to Jeffrey Epstein. The files, expected to be ready by Thursday COB, involve approximately 5-6 iMacs and 5 laptop computers processed by CART. An Assistant U.S. Attorney is following up on the status of these files and requesting information regarding materials from the island that require processing, along with an estimated completion time.

Key points include: *   **Slotkin's Motivation:** Slotkin’s personal connection to the issue stems from her former CIA analyst role, her son-in-law’s service at an Iraqi base, and her family’s military service background. She frames the resolution as a necessary check on presidential power due to her concerns about potential escalation. *   **Republican Opposition:** Republican lawmakers, particularly Kevin McCarthy and Lindsey Graham, heavily criticize Slotkin and the resolution, framing it as unpatriotic and potentially empowering the enemy. They highlight the personal investment Slotkin has in the conflict. *   **Senate Support:** Senator Tim Kaine, a key sponsor of the resolution, shares a similar personal connection – his son is a Marine infantry officer deployed overseas. He is working to secure enough Republican support for passage. *   **Escalating Tensions:** The situation is further complicated by the downing of a Ukrainian airliner near Tehran, with growing speculation about U.S. involvement and heightened tensions with Iran, including a renewed condemnation of the nuclear deal. *   **Political Maneuvering:** The GOP is attempting to discredit the resolution, with some openly mocking Slotkin and questioning her motivations. Other Republican voices, like Matt Gaetz, defend her actions, pointing to her military service. *   **Other Developments:** The document also covers a range of related political developments, including: the narrowing support for Joe Biden in the Democratic primary, ongoing debate over the impeachment articles, and revelations about Jared Kushner’s diminished role in the administration. It mentions a controversial charity event for Pence and a Republican senator’s meeting with a Democratic colleague about climate change. Finally, it details an attempt by a former presidential candidate, Marianne Williamson, to raise awareness about the situation.

The document is a series of email exchanges concerning the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein investigation. Key points include: *   Discussions about locating data within the Relativity database, specifically regarding folders named "2020-01-23" and "Search Warrant Returns." *   Reports on the release of data from the NP and STR folders, with delays attributed to large data volumes. *   Confirmation of a hard drive received from FBI CART containing seized device materials. *   Requests for the hard drive to be returned after data upload for subsequent privilege review. *   Multiple inquiries regarding the status of data uploads and delays.

On February 7, 2020, an individual requested an update on the upload of materials from an FBI CART hard drive containing data from seized and searched devices related to the Epstein case. The hard drive was received on January 21, 2020, and left with the recipient. The materials were to be uploaded to Relativity for privilege review, mirroring a previous review of Epstein search warrant returns. A subsequent batch of materials was anticipated shortly after the first upload.

An email chain discusses the receipt of a hard drive from the FBI CART containing materials from the Epstein case. The drive was processed from seized devices and includes data for upload and privilege review to Relativity. A follow-up email requests the return of the hard drive after the materials are uploaded, anticipating another FBI transmission. The privilege review is to be conducted identically to a previous review related to Epstein search warrant returns.

Emails discuss the upload and privilege review of data from a hard drive received from the FBI CART related to the Epstein case. The hard drive contains processed devices seized and searched. A request is made to upload the materials to Relativity for privilege review. A follow-up email inquires about the status of the upload, and another confirms the materials will be subject to a similar privilege review as previous Epstein search warrant returns. A second hard drive with additional materials is expected shortly.

Emails discuss the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case, originating from an FBI CART hard drive. The data was expected to be ready by the end of the week, with updates provided regarding its status. Instructions were given for PAE to categorize the data into PP and NP folders based on privilege terms and to send STR reports. The recipient requested the hard drive back once the materials were uploaded for a subsequent privilege review mirroring a previous process.

Email correspondence regarding the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case, originating from an FBI CART hard drive. The data was initially expected to be completed within a day but was delayed. Updates indicated the data was “almost done” by February 12th, then expected to be ready by Monday morning. A check-in was made on February 4th regarding the status. The hard drive was received on January 21st and intended to be uploaded to Relativity for privilege review, with a request for its return after completion.

*   **Judge Resignation:** A Kansas federal judge resigned amidst allegations of sexual harassment, an affair, and tardiness. *   **USPTO Rule Changes:** The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office modified a rule requiring trademark owners to post their email addresses. *   **Trump Commutations & Waivers:** President Trump commuted the sentence of Rod Blagojevich and authorized the Trump administration to waive federal procurement laws to expedite the construction of the border wall. *   **EPA Watchdog Report:** The EPA’s internal watchdog criticized the regulator’s monitoring of the Mexico border program. *   **DC Circuit Ruling:** The D.C. Circuit Court ruled the House of Representatives cannot sue the President over funding disputes. *   **NCLA Challenges:** The New Civil Liberties Alliance (NCLA) supported challenges to the SEC administrative law judges and to a shrinking TCPA’s reach. *   **Bloomberg Proposals:** Michael Bloomberg proposed a financial transaction tax and student loan debt relief. *   **South Carolina Litigation:** A federal judge continued litigation challenging oil-and-gas seismic testing off the Atlantic Coast. *   **EPA Water Rule Criticism:** Environmental groups criticized the EPA’s new water regulation for allegedly ignoring potential impacts on endangered species. *   **ACA Appeal:** Republican state attorneys general urged the Supreme Court to reject an appeal protecting the Affordable Care Act. *   **AI in Patent Examination:** The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office is experimenting with AI in patent examination but raises concerns about due process and labor. *   **Other Notable Cases:** Several other legal developments were reported including: Restaurant groups cannot challenge NYC fair work week law; TSMC challenges Huawei; Former Teva exec slams price-fixing claims;  Texas judge rules Huawei contracting ban is constitutional;  DC Circ. wary that House can't sue Prez over funding rows, EU adds Cayman Islands to tax haven blacklist. **Firm & Personnel News** *   Several law firms announced hires and developments, including BakerHostetler, Fox Rothschild, Kirkland & Ellis, and Morrison & Foerster, as well as the appointment of Mark Filip as monitoring trustee for Live Nation. **Job Postings** *   Two job listings were included: one for a Products Liability Associate at McCarter & English and another for an Assistant Attorney General - Public Access Bureau position with the Illinois Attorney General's Office.
keywords: attorney - assistant attorney general - public access bureau

timeline.summary: Multiple individuals are discussing the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case, specifically data received from the FBI CART. The data includes a hard drive processed from seized devices. Upload progress is being tracked, with updates stating the data is “large” and taking time to process. There are requests for status updates and confirmation of completion. A timeline of Monday morning is referenced for data readiness, and a follow-up is scheduled regarding the return of the hard drive once the data is uploaded.

The following emails discuss the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein investigation: *   Multiple individuals are requesting updates on the status of data received from the FBI CART, including a hard drive containing seized device materials. *   The data is initially located in the "Subpoena Returns" folder, then the “Search Warrant Returns” folder, and later in the “NP” and “STR” folders. *   The data is being segregated into “PP” hits and new data is loaded. *   The FBI is processing multiple hard drives related to the case. *   The privilege review process is being conducted, mirroring previous reviews of Epstein search warrant returns. *   The FBI anticipates further data transmissions.

Several individuals are discussing the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case. The data, initially from FBI CART hard drives, is being processed and segmented into folders including "Subpoena Returns," "Search Warrant Returns," "NP," and "PP hits." There are requests for consolidation of subfolders and confirmation of data accessibility within Relativity. Updates regarding data loading progress and delays are provided throughout the exchange. This document is a Curriculum Vitae for an FBI Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) expert witness. The individual has over 15 years of experience as a Computer Forensic Examiner, starting in 2005 with the FBI New York Field Office. Their experience includes analyzing over 1000 pieces of computer media in over 300 cases, conducting search warrant operations, and providing expert testimony in Federal Court.  Prior to the FBI, they held various roles in programming and data administration at Viecore, Inc. and Erisco, Inc. They possess advanced educational qualifications including a Master’s in Digital Forensics and Cyber Security and a Bachelor’s in Business and Computer Science.  The CV details extensive forensic training and certifications across multiple tools and platforms, including EnCase, FTK, Cellebrite, and various mobile forensics techniques, highlighting ongoing professional development and specialized skills.
